body: Just back from vacation, added [issue ](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TINKERPOP-2268)in JIRA

thanks @aholmberg  and @TheRealFalcon - i got rid of hacks (and the "old" way in general) in exchange for `calendar` . I didn't use the full DS driver code in terms of error handling because this code should only get triggered for actual `datetime` sorts of objects. if the timestamp was a numeric i think it believe it would have ended up being handled by that serializer.

Thanks for doing that. For other committers reviewing, I will handle changelog update on merge.

All tests pass with `docker/build.sh -t -i`

VOTE +1

This approach seems fine to me. Could you please update the reference documentation with this new options:

https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/1213d3f8276da14ae3854ec16e46b0a2ab2e897e/docs/src/reference/gremlin-applications.asciidoc#console-preferences

A CHANGELOG entry would also make this one fully complete. I don't mind adding both of those items on merge if you can't come back to this one immediately.

VOTE +1

Thanks for taking a look and giving guidance.  I just followed up on both of your points, amended the commit, and force-pushed.

I tried to stick to the CHANGELOG file's established convention, so I added an Improvements subsection under 3.4.3 with a single bullet point listing the JIRA key and a one-liner description.

I also updated the asciidoc's table of console prefs.  I couldn't identify a sort on that table, so I just inserted warnings after colors, the only other boolean-typed option.  Here's a link to how it looks on the PR now:

https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/82de2a60fcff81643008e3b11f5fef358bc8808e/docs/src/reference/gremlin-applications.asciidoc#console-preferences
sorry, but for changelog you just needed to add another bullet to the list - the actual "JIRA stuff" gets added on release. thanks
Merged this to a new branch shown in PR #1168 - assuming that's ok, we will merge from there and close this one out.
Sure thing. Thank you for taking it up and apologies for leaving it open for such a long time. Your suggestions regarding deprecation makes sense now, will take care in future code.

Looks good. 

Vote +1: I understand the motivation of this change and am familiar with the logic of the change.

I deleted the issue key and the Improvements subsection, so now it's just a bullet with a commit-message-like description.

Also, I just changed the github PR's target branch from master to tp34.  I branched off tp34 when I started working on this.  I just overlooked the target dropdown when opening the PR here on github.

Let me know if you actually wanted this to go into master and didn't want the target changed to tp34.  I think there will be a CHANGELOG conflict.  I can rebase and fix/resolve in that case though.
hmm - i thought it was already targeted at tp34 when you submitted it, so if you had to change it to be so, then it's in the right place.  Anyway, looks all good now - thank you
Note that there is a committer +1 on the JIRA issue.
What's the status on this?  I would be very interested in this browser based approach.  Any idea when/if this will be incorporated?

As a quick update from my perspective....My [comments on this issue from 2/28](https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/pull/1070#issuecomment-468352633) still stand I think. If those items get done I think this one would be ready for review. I would add that at this point this PR should probably be rebased on `tp34` branch as `master` is now for 3.5.0.  We are currently starting the release process for 3.4.3 so this PR is probably headed for 3.4.4 or later at this point.  Thanks for inquiring @shanequint
Perfect.

@divijvaidya i was reviewing a bit in preparation for release next week and I think i have some questions related to this change:

1. Was there a reason why `TinkerGraphIterator` didn't implement our `CloseableIterator`?
2. Going a step further, was there a reason not to somehow fold the functionality of the `TinkerGraphIterator` into `CloseableIterator` infrastructure?

It seems like, at a minimum, we should do item 1 which is pretty painless. For item 2, I guess `DefaultCloseableIterator` could take much of the functionality of the `TinkerGraphIterator` and then we'd use `CloseableIterator.asCloseable()` in these sorts of places:

https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/pull/1118/files#diff-e146457e1c98d0e94695d31b0e5ed6f4

thoughts?

We can do 1 but I don't see a lot of benefit of doing this. Having said that, I don't have any strong opinion on this. Will change.

But for 2, I would keep prefer that `CloseableIterator` and `DefaultCloseableIterator` act as extensions to vanilla iterator operators (as their name suggests) without any domain specific business logic.

`TinkerGraphIterator` contains storage specific logic, i.e. knowledge of when to increment/decrement `StoreIteratorCounter` (different storage might release the iterator at different events) and hence, I am not in favor of adding its functionality to `DefaultCloseableIterator`.

>  Having said that, I don't have any strong opinion on this. Will change.

ok...i will look for a PR. i think that we should consistently try to use that `CloseableIterator` interface. it was created explicitly for this purpose (requested by OrientDB originally i believe). 

I'm going to sleep on your reasoning for 2, but what you're saying there sounds right to me.

thanks for taking the time to contribute to the project. could you say some more about the performance issues - is there a noticeable improvement as a result of this change?

> thanks for taking the time to contribute to the project. could you say some more about the performance issues - is there a noticeable improvement as a result of this change? VOTE +1
VOTE +1
VOTE +1

Please note that travis is failing the build at this point. The error appears consistent across the different builds, so I think it's a legitimate problem with your changes and not travis instability.

Hi @WiredUK and thanks for contributing to TinkerPop!

Is the `NullReferenceException` you're getting the same as described in [TINKERPOP-2192](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TINKERPOP-2192)?
If not, can you please provide a stack trace?
I would like to understand the problem better before I can really review this PR.

> Is the `NullReferenceException` you're getting the same as described in [TINKERPOP-2192](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/TINKERPOP-2192)?

Hmm, it could be, it's definitely happening around the same part of the code. But if it is, your deduction about the cause is slightly off I think. Note that the NREs that I am seeing are not exposed outside the Gremlin.Net library, they just get logged in the output window. Everything works fine, it's just slowing things down.

> If not, can you please provide a stack trace?

Sure, stack trace is:

```
at Gremlin.Net.Driver.Connection.TryParseResponseMessage(ResponseMessage`1 receivedMsg) in C:\path\Gremlin.Net\Driver\Connection.cs:line 136
at Gremlin.Net.Driver.Connection.Parse(Byte[] received) in C:\path\Gremlin.Net\Driver\Connection.cs:line 123
```

The error happens because `Parse` is receiving an empty byte array, which in turn makes `_messageSerializer.DeserializeMessage<ResponseMessage<JToken>>(received)` return `null`.

> But if it is, your deduction about the cause is slightly off I think.

That's definitely possible. I didn't have the line numbers for the stack trace which probably resulted in me looking in the wrong place.

> The error happens because Parse is receiving an empty byte array, which in turn makes _messageSerializer.DeserializeMessage<ResponseMessage<JToken>>(received) return null.

Isn't it then enough to just check whether we received an empty array from `_webSocketConnection.ReceiveMessageAsync()` and then skip the `Parse` method?
Then we wouldn't need an additional class just transmit information about whether we actually received anything or not because the connection was already closed.
We already [check regularly whether a connection is already closed](https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/54873cb6de65f0f610fa2a35e970b4c327a0a040/gremlin-dotnet/src/Gremlin.Net/Driver/ConnectionPool.cs#L127) in the `ConnectionPool` so I would prefer if we could not add another check like that here.

> Isn't it then enough to just check whether we received an empty array from `_webSocketConnection.ReceiveMessageAsync()` and then skip the `Parse` method?
> Then we wouldn't need an additional class just transmit information about whether we actually received anything or not because the connection was already closed.
> We already [check regularly whether a connection is already closed](https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/54873cb6de65f0f610fa2a35e970b4c327a0a040/gremlin-dotnet/src/Gremlin.Net/Driver/ConnectionPool.cs#L127) in the `ConnectionPool` so I would prefer if we could not add another check like that here.

Maybe, but then the code gets "stuck" inside the `while(true)`, which is a tight loop, waiting for the external connection check, and only exits when an exception happens. There seems to be no way to check that all messages have been received?

> Maybe, but then the code gets "stuck" inside the while(true), which is a tight loop, waiting for the external connection check, and only exits when an exception happens.

But it will only call `ReceiveMessageAsync` as that shouldn't return any more if the connection is already closed, right?

> > Maybe, but then the code gets "stuck" inside the while(true), which is a tight loop, waiting for the external connection check, and only exits when an exception happens.
> 
> But it will only call `ReceiveMessageAsync` as that shouldn't return any more if the connection is already closed, right?

If I just add a check around the received message being null, as per [this image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7810709/62474546-06002f00-b79b-11e9-98f7-cf175dd10900.png), the errors switch to being `WebSocketException` because it continues to keep trying to receive more messages.

Another option would be to return a flag from the `Parse` method which would allow breaking out of `ReceiveMessagesAsync`. If you are confident the connections ae managed elsewhere, that could work. For example https://gist.github.com/WiredUK/7b356eaa15b3c2615a3e45e28f8b950b

it looks like this is a really good bug fix. what kind of error do you get without this change? is it a reflection error?

I'd ask that you please do make the following additional changes:

1. rebase this change on the `tp34` branch (note that we are currently releasing 3.4.3 so rebasing will put you on that version rather than "-SNAPSHOT" - you may wish to bump to 3.4.4-SNAPSHOT or wait until I do it later this week. note that we won't be able to merge this until `tp34` is re-opened for development after release is complete).
2. add a test to Gremlin Server that ensures DSLs work with your newly added constructor and `AnonymousTraversalSource`. if you base your new test case on [AbstractGremlinServerIntegrationTest](https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/2f6b2a7adda5c498a8d318197208d6f84d5cbe5d/gremlin-server/src/test/java/org/apache/tinkerpop/gremlin/server/AbstractGremlinServerIntegrationTest.java) you will get a running Gremlin Server instance you can establish your connection to
3. Please add a CHANGELOG entry for your fix (again, you may wish to wait until we bump back to "-SNAPSHOT" before doing this so that the new version is setup and templated for you.

Thanks for taking the time to provide this fix.

Thanks for your PR. Should this be targetted at the master branch or would it be better backported to tp33 so that it will be available on the current release lines of 3.3.x and 3.4.x?

Note that if you do rebase this PR, those release branches are currently not on "-SNAPSHOT" versions as we are in the middle of the release process right now. You will likely need to rebase again toward the end of the week when we reopen them for business.

Thanks, @spmallette . It's better if this PR can be absorbed in next release of 3.3.x and 3.4.x.
I will rebase again after branch reopened.

Hi, @spmallette.

An InvocationTargetException like the following one will be throw, if the constructor was not generated for the traversal source class.

I added a test for this. I will do the rebase and update the CHANGELOG once the `tp34` branch is bumped to 3.4.4-SNAPSHOT.

```
java.lang.reflect.InvocationTargetException
	at org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.process.traversal.dsl.GremlinDslProcessorTest.shouldCompileRemoteDslTraversal(GremlinDslProcessorTest.java:87)
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.process.traversal.dsl.SocialTraversalSource.<init>(org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.process.remote.RemoteConnection)
	at org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.process.traversal.dsl.GremlinDslProcessorTest.shouldCompileRemoteDslTraversal(GremlinDslProcessorTest.java:87)
Caused by: java.lang.NoSuchMethodException: org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.process.traversal.dsl.SocialTraversalSource.<init>(org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.process.remote.RemoteConnection)
	at org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.process.traversal.dsl.GremlinDslProcessorTest.shouldCompileRemoteDslTraversal(GremlinDslProcessorTest.java:87)
```

> If I just add a check around the received message being null, as per this image, the errors switch to being WebSocketException because it continues to keep trying to receive more messages.

I didn't expect that to be honest. In that case, I'd actually prefer your approach in this PR to directly close the connection if it's broken indicated by the received empty array.

> If you are confident the connections ae managed elsewhere, that could work. 

I guess it actually makes more sense to close the connection here directly if we know for sure at that point that it isn't usable any more instead of letting it sit in the `ConnectionPool` and let that detect and handle the problem.

Another point that needs to be taken care of are the requests currently awaiting a response over the connection that we close here. We can notify them similar to how the `NotifyAboutConnectionFailure` method currently does it.

@jorgebay If you have some time to spare, it would be good to have your input here, too.
I agree about closing the connection eagerly and notifying the existing requests that there is a connection error (in the same way as `NotifyAboutConnectionFailure()`).

The current flow is for it to throw an exception, which bubbles up and causes the connection to be closed via the `CloseConnectionBecauseOfFailureAsync` method. If that exception is no longer being thrown, we cannot call that method any more because it requires the exception object to be passed in (ultimately so it can notify)

I'm now wondering if the whole connection flow needs to be reviewed because this PR would fix the "control flow by exception" (which imo is an anti-pattern) but may have other side effects.

>  If that exception is no longer being thrown, we cannot call that method any more because it requires the exception object to be passed in (ultimately so it can notify)

I think we can either add a very similar method that doesn't take an exception or to just create an exception object and pass that to the method.

> I'm now wondering if the whole connection flow needs to be reviewed because this PR would fix the "control flow by exception" (which imo is an anti-pattern)

I wouldn't call it control flow by exception right now as the driver simply doesn't catch this exception as we didn't expect it. So, it's really an unexpected exception for which the error handling seems appropriate to me. This PR changes that as it checks for the error and then handles it by notifying all affected request handlers with a meaningful message instead of the `NullReferenceException` (at least per my above suggestion).

The reason I said it is flow-by-exception is because of the `while(true)` loop. The only way to leave that loop is by exception. It may not have been intended to be used that way, but that is how it is currently written. 

I don't know enough about the notification process to update this PR right now, I'd need to dig into it further to make another update. Happy to take guidance though.
The tp33 has been re-opened for development and is set to 3.3.9-SNAPSHOT. Please feel free to rebase now.
The tp34 has been re-opened for development and is set to 3.4.4-SNAPSHOT. Please feel free to rebase now.
The tp33 branch has been re-opened for development and is set to 3.3.9-SNAPSHOT. Please feel free to rebase.
Thanks for reminding. Rebased already.

My idea was simply to do something like this if the connection was closed unexpectedly:

```c#
await CloseConnectionBecauseOfFailureAsync(
    new Exception("The connection was closed while receiving.")).ConfigureAwait(false);
```

Of course a more specific exception type than `Exception` should be used, but I haven't looked yet into which one could be a good candidate here.
This could be done in the `Connection` class. An alternative approach would simply throw a meaningful exception directly in the `WebSocketConnection` class where you currently check whether the connection was closed. That would of course again rely on exception handling to deal with this error, but I'm not even sure if that isn't the most appropriate approach here as that really is an error case in my opinion which justifies exception handling.

Both approaches terminate waiting requests and notify users about the occurred exception which is the right approach in my opinion. The fact the Cosmos DB for some reason just seems to close connections that we still consider to be active is a different problem that we need to address separately from this problem of getting a hard to understand `NullReferenceException`.

Thanks for offering this update - I saw this project a while back and forgot to do it.

VOTE +1

@spmallette This merge request is ready for reviewing. It basically follows the same idea as your previous work in the TINKERPOP-2132 branch, which has been there for a while, but is not merged for some reason I wander. 

In this commit, I added a step that sends a validation request at the end of the constructor of `Connection`. So, we don't have to introduce a new message or change the client code to use a new channalizer. I also changed the exception handling of validation, so that `ResponseException`s do not fail the validation,  because in the case when `strictTransactionManagement` is enabled, the validation fails for sure with a `ResponseException`, but the client is still ok for correctly built messages with explicit aliases.

There are some other points I think may worth a change but not included in this commit in order to minimize the modifications.
1. The TimeoutException thrown when no host is available is a little bit misleading. Maybe a specialized `NoHostAvailableException` is better.
2. It's a commonly used pattern to catch checked exceptions and wrap them in `RuntimeException`s and re-throw. It might become a performance killer when exceptions happen very quickly, because of the expensive `fillInStackTrace` method invocation.

OK - i didn't have the right reproduction steps - tested this change manually:

```text
gremlin> g.V().hasId([]).has('name','marko').profile()
java.lang.NullPointerException
Type ':help' or ':h' for help.
Display stack trace? [yN]y
java.lang.NullPointerException
```

after the change:

```text
gremlin> g.V().hasId([]).has('name','marko').profile()
==>Traversal Metrics
Step                                                               Count  Traversers       Time (ms)    % Dur
=============================================================================================================
TinkerGraphStep(vertex,[name.eq(marko)])                                                       1.108   100.00
                                            >TOTAL                     -           -           1.108        -
```

Merging. Thanks.
Merged - thank you.
I just wanted to call attention to my previous comment from a few weeks back - unfortunately, we can't easily evaluate/review this PR unless the commit history is cleaned up a bit.
Since it's been a few months, I was just wondering if you intended to come back to this PR any time soon?
Given the discussion on the JIRA issue, it seems that we won't do this one - closing.

Thanks for this pull request. As a note to other reviewers, I will add the CHANGELOG entry on merge.

VOTE +1

> It basically follows the same idea as your previous work in the TINKERPOP-2132 branch, which has been there for a while, but is not merged for some reason I wander.

I mentioned in the JIRA ticket why I didn't merge it. It introduced a breaking change to the Gremlin Server protocol to properly fix it and I didn't want to do that for 3.3.x or 3.4.x. I think it would be best if we could avoid that if at all possible as it means previous versions of the driver won't be able to connect along those release lines.

> In this commit, I added a step that sends a validation request at the end of the constructor of Connection.

So, I suppose this approach is a possible solution. You eagerly do the authentication operation of the `Connection` by way of a validation message. I guess that the `Connection` does the websocket handshake in the constructor, so immediately sending a validation message to force authentication might not have bad consequences. It's not an elegant solution, but if this problem is really bothering people and no other non-breaking solutions can be found then I suppose we could go with it ([assuming the tests](https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/pull/1187#discussion_r320410110) show this fix actually does solve the problem).

> not included in this commit in order to minimize the modifications.

Thank you - that is appreciated.

> The TimeoutException thrown when no host is available is a little bit misleading. Maybe a specialized NoHostAvailableException is better.

I think i made a note about that elsewhere in my review. The `TimeoutException` isn't so good. 

> It's a commonly used pattern to catch checked exceptions and wrap them in RuntimeExceptions and re-throw

Yeah - I think the exception handling could be better. The generalized `RuntimeException` isn't so nice. It would be nice to make that better if we could introduce improvements without breaking changes, but that seems hard at this point. It might need to wait until 3.5.0...not sure.

Basically [this comment](https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/pull/1108#issuecomment-489690861) summarizes reasoning and direction with this one at this point. Going to re-write the JIRA issue with that in mind.

Thanks for your patch @danielcweber !

I'm not sure the problem you are trying to solve, is it just making the code more readable?

The `Connection` is a low level class, C# doesn't have something like Netty that simplifies sending/receiving with thread safe channels, so IMO its OK to have low level code (queues, CAS ops, ...).

Semaphores have a cost when contended, you can look at the WaitAsync() lock here: https://github.com/dotnet/coreclr/blob/master/src/System.Private.CoreLib/shared/System/Threading/SemaphoreSlim.cs#L623

I would find very hard to +1 a patch like this without any additional tests and/or performance tests.
@FlorianHockmann What do you think?

The improvement in my patch is that it achieves what the original code did (queueing up items asynchronously), but by means of a higher level construct (SemaphoreSlim vs. combination of queues, CAS, etc.). I found the original code hard to reason about, as lock-free code usually is. [My original workaround](https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/pull/1114) already fixed a bug that had slipped through unnoticed for quite some time.

Yes, SemaphoreSlim does contain a synchrounous lock, but I don't see that this is a problem per se. The driver as a whole is not designed to be lock-free in every part, which is usually just fine.
I backported this to `tp32` as 29e61312905301cb8f4f32469ab712821705ecf5 and merged forward. Closing.

I agree that the implementation of `Connection` is hard to reason about and I'm definitely open to improvements on that front! But the driver is currently lock-free which is definitely a nice property to have and I would prefer if we could keep it that way. So, we need a good reason to introduce locks again in my opinion.

Apart from that, using a `SemaphoreSlim` is a bit problematic in general as it guarantees no order in which threads can enter the semaphore. In the extreme case where the user configures the pool to use just one connection with a high number of parallel requests for that connection, the situation can occur that some writes have to wait for a long time because new writes come in and are executed first.
So the direction here is: No locks in any code in the driver nor in the framework classes it uses?
Yes,  i will continue this PR  later  this week,  Thanks for your remind

> So the direction here is: No locks in any code in the driver nor in the framework classes it uses?

No, I wouldn't go so far to ban locks completely from all code in the driver, including its dependencies. The recently introduced `CopyOnWriteCollection` for example [also uses locks](https://github.com/apache/tinkerpop/blob/c951abe4a80a3df59e46f70c8265100f00cf22a3/gremlin-dotnet/src/Gremlin.Net/Driver/CopyOnWriteCollection.cs#L41) (so the driver isn't completely lock-free, strictly speaking). I think that's ok in this case as it only needs locks to change the size of the collection, so for resizing operations of the connection pool. We want to move these operations out of the usual execution flow of requests as much as possible, ideally they are only performed by dedicated tasks executed in the background (and only in error cases).
If we have a good reason to introduce locks in the driver (and we're confident that it won't lead to deadlocks and only block threads for such a small time period that it's basically neglectable), then we can do so in my opinion.

For this specific PR, I'm not really convinced yet that the benefit of making the code easier to reason about warrants the added lock, especially because the lock needs to be acquired for every request and because this solution comes with the other disadvantage I mentioned about not having a guaranteed order with the `SemaphoreSlim`.
All the tests passed except the last one. It seems caused by some test environment problem rather than the code changes.

Wow. Rad PR man. Love your README.

Goodness to you,
Marko.

> On Sep 7, 2019, at 7:35 PM, Rusi Popov <notifications@github.com> wrote:
> 
> [TINKERPOP-2274] Fixed the issues revealed while compiling and running tests under Windows
> 
> File system differences
> 
> Revealed that the Spark context is not closed between the tests, while the tests remove its storage files, therefore explicitluy store Spark Cintext for every test, making the tests independent and (more) corect on Spark use.
> 
> Revealed that Spark does not close the FileInputStreams it iterates upon, so that locks hang up in the file system. Thus, not being able to fix Spark/Hadoop and specifically the use of MultiIterator, call explicitly System.gc() in order to finalize the streams remaining open after closing the context.
> 
> In Windows the file locking is diffrent than in LINUX, so rm() tests failed.
> 
> See: [https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SPARK-12216]
> 
> Documentaton
> 
> Documented the convention to use only UNIX-formatted file paths as of the Storage API.
> Revealed the use and documented the Storage interface.
> File names and conventions
> 
> Delegated file parsing to File class for platform independence
> Migrated to use unform UNIX-formatted paths, even under Windows for platform indepenence.
> Imposed Path / File classes use instead of manually composing file names.
> Avoided strings as Storage file system paths.
> Resolved inconsistency of Storage (file system) API returning null.
> Refactored FileSystemStorage to match the use & specification.
> Fixed possible leaking resources.
> Fixed inconsistencies in the use of / and home directory.
> Changed Storage.rm() to report if it succeeded to remove at least a file (in scope).
> Changed Spark tests close use the non-persistent context, this way closing it when not needed
> Changed tests
> 
> Fixed EarlyLimitStrategyTest to allow running it
> Fixed the loger matching tests to ignore platform-specific EOLN char(s)
> Fixed org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.hadoop.process.computer.AbstractHadoopGraphComputerTest to delete the temorary files first before attempting to create new ones with the same name. Provided better error diagnostic messages.
> Renamed org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.TestHelper to CoreTestHelper to avoid confusing it with other TestHelper class.
> Updated AbstractStorageCheck#AbstractStorageCheck tests to ease their understanding and help further improvement of error reporting. Fixed the tests of rm(), cp() methods.
> Fixed tests
> 
> org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.spark.SparkGremlinGryoSerializerTest
> org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.spark.SparkGremlinTest
> that used to fail with:
> ERROR shouldSupportCopyMethods(org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.spark.structure.io.SparkContextStorageCheck)
> java.lang.AssertionError
> at org.apache.tinkerpop.gremlin.spark.structure.io.SparkContextStorageCheck.shouldSupportCopyMethods(SparkContextStorageCheck.java:75)
> (NOTE: this is an example of "cryptic" error message reported on failed tests)
> Fixed reflection-based test to match their parameters at runtime.
> Dates
> 
> Used SimpleDateFormat with explicit US locale to parse the test data.
> POM changes
> 
> Changed POM to dump the whole stack trace in case of test failure.
> 
> Set POM to check if HADOOP_HOME and HADOOP_GREMLIN_LIBS env. vars are set and warn if not, in order not to fail the build with NullPointerException.
> 
> In order to avoid MAVEN warnings, provided explicitly the most-recent version of jacoco in and removed .
> 
> Made the required HADOOP_HOME and HADOOP_GREMLIN_LIBS set up optional to allow Travis build pass, but this basically negates the use of Maven enforcer at all - in case of not installed Hadoop the tests will fail with no indication why, instead of the script to define & test its environment clearly.
> 
> Artifacts
> 
> Added generation of the tests jar to publish the TestHelper class, that is used both in core and tests projects, as a preparation to avoid the collistion of TestHelper classes in both projects
> In hadoop project added Readme.md to describe how to install hadoop, spark and OS integration.

On merge I re-instated `GSSException` assertions as different environments will throw that occasionally (yet another problem with exceptions in the java driver), added changelog and some upgrade docs. Thanks!
